video.title: JavaScript Programming - Full Course
video.description:
Learn JavaScript from scratch by solving over a hundred different coding challenges. Go here for the interactive browser version: https://scrimba.com/learn/learnjavascript

⭐️ Code ⭐️
Two versions:
🔗 Interactive version: https://scrimba.com/learn/learnjavascript
🔗 GitHub repo: https://github.com/scrimba/learn-javascript

✏️ Created by Per Harald Borgen. Per on Twitter: https://twitter.com/perborgen

topLevelComment.author: ardentype
topLevelComment.text:
Can someone please clear up this doubt?

At 5:25:55 when creating the renderLeads function, is it mandatory to define the listItems variable inside the function instead of outside?

When I defined the listItems variable outside of the renderLeads function, I mean just above it, the outcome when the save input button was clicked was different, I mean some of the leads are appearing more than once.

Can someone pls explain why the outcome is different?

replies.author: Neo Documenting my Journey
replies.text: @ardentype i edited it to remove spelling mistakes so you can understand it if you didn't before

replies.author: ardentype
replies.text: @Neo Documenting my Journey thanks for clearing that up.

replies.author: Neo Documenting my Journey
replies.text: Its because that line being outside of the function isn't running everytime you are rendering the list. Having it inside means that list items will be cleared and just be " " every time render function is called. So there is no text from last time there

topLevelComment.author: Ted N
topLevelComment.text:
For those who are saying this tutorial is not so good because it has too many complicated concepts:
I watched it 3 weeks ago and did not understand anything. But now I'm learning everything on this video. How?
Because I realized that to learn from such big tutorials you need to learn the "basic of the basic" first.
There aren't many tutorials that teach the very beginners like myself. Fortunately I was able to find an AWESOME book, it's called "Javascript in Less Than 50 Pages", I recommend it to anyone who is a very beginner, before start watching any big tutorial.
Learning the basics first is how you can dive into more complex, more complicated video tutorials.

topLevelComment.author: Sudhanshu Gorwadkar
topLevelComment.text:
Important tip:- If the links rendered under the SAVE INPUT button do not open, just add two forward slashes in the href attribute string in the anchor tag in the renderLeads() function.
Hence, the syntax will be, <a target='_blank' href='//${myLeads[i]}'>

But remove those slashes while deploying the final version of the extension.

Hope this helps!

topLevelComment.author: Jonathan Fritzing Bob
topLevelComment.text:
Thanks for your great video!
Just a comment: during your demo, when defining href attribute for "a" tags, you're omitting "http://". Is it done on purpose? At least, on my chrome browser, it requires to add "http://" to reach the website (if not, this is a relative link).

replies.author: Sudhanshu Gorwadkar
replies.text:
Adding "https://" or "http://" or just "//" is initially necessary, but it causes the added lead links to open with an incorrect link after deploying the final version of the extension.

So just add that into the href attribute while building the app and remove it while deploying the final version.

topLevelComment.author: Frank Solinsky
topLevelComment.text:
Hands down, Per is the best instructor I have ever had the pleasure of learning from.
As someone who struggles with ADHD, this course was definitely efficient at keeping me engaged and wanting to learn.

Per provides a fun and relaxing environment to learn in. I still can't believe how much information I was able to effectively consume.
Better still, I feel like I've actually retained it in a useful way. Per's teaching method definitely requires you to develop a strong muscle memory.

I still needed to go back and look at a previous lesson for help, Google for answers or watch Per's solutions to understand at times, but I definitely was
able to figure out a lot more on my own than I normally am when I try to learn new things.

Thank you so much, for helping me see that I really love programming and Javascript.

topLevelComment.author: TinyMaths
topLevelComment.text:
Here's an interesting tip:
Once you've learned how to use the 'onclick' property with the button element, why not create a temporary button  on your app specifically for control-logging anything you need to debug.  You can create a function in JS and have console.log() inside of it. Link that to your button, and then whenever you need to console log something, like in the exercises for example, you can just enter the required variable inside console.log() within your function, and then click the button on your app, and, VOILA, console-logged!  

It's not necessary but it's a nice touch and then you won't have to keep on typing out console.log() for each exercise.  It's also a fun exercise in itself.  You can always remove the button later when your app is complete.

replies.author: TinyMaths
replies.text:
Try searching 'VAR vs LET' here on YouTube.  It's beyond the scope of this tutorial; basically 'var' makes a variable available 'anywhere' in the function, but let is only available at the block level.

here's a basic example:

if (randomCard === 21){ var message = "  you win "}
Console.log(message)

when you get 21, your message will be logged to the console, but, if you did this below (using 'let' instead): 

if (randomCard === 21){  let message = "  you win "}
Console.log(message)
because the console.log(message) is outside of the block where the 'let' was used to create a variable, you will get an error telling you that 'message' is undefined. 

instead you would have to do as below:

if (randomCard === 21){ let message = "  you win ";
Console.log(message)
}

So now, your console.log(message) is INSIDE the block and you will have access to in, because you are console logging from inside the 'block' where the variable is assigned using 'let' 

I don't quite understand the differences, and why they are so important, but there are explanations if you search for them. I'm just not at that level yet.  

Regarding the use of semi-colons, I think their use is largely for  'semantic' purposes, it's the end of a statement which is easy to see when you have a semi-colon, but I don't think they are absolutely necessary in JS, as you can see in this lecture.

topLevelComment.text:
When I try to grab html element in a variable like let number=getElementById ("main");
And console log it. It says the variable is null,why? Please help me.

replies.author: Ankur Waghmare
replies.text: @Stefan Vasilica ok thank you so much.

replies.author: Stefan Vasilica
replies.text: @Ankur Waghmare The reason for this is that HTML loads from top to bottom. The head loads first, then the body, and then everything inside the body. If we put our JavaScript in the head section, the entire JavaScript will load before loading any of the HTML, which could cause a few problems.

replies.author: Ankur Waghmare
replies.text: @Stefan Vasilica thank you so much it worked. I was really frustrated due to this from past few days.but what's logic behind this?

replies.author: Stefan Vasilica
replies.text: write your script tag at the end of the body tag
